channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: Gavin Newsom Is Playing the Long Game
item.description: California’s governor has been touted as the Democrats’ best shot in 2028. But first he’ll need to convince voters that he’s not just a slick establishment politician.

item.title: David Remnick on S. N. Behrman’s “The Days of Duveen”
item.description: In a wry Profile of the British-born art dealer Joseph Duveen, Behrman captures the workings of a canny commercial intelligence wreathed in connoisseurship and charm.

item.title: Living in Tracy Chapman’s House
item.description: Fresh out of college, we were a bunch of misfits, in a chaotic, run-down communal home, desperately trying to figure out who we were meant to be.

item.title: Deepfaking Orson Welles’s Mangled Masterpiece
item.description: Will an A.I. restoration of “The Magnificent Ambersons” right a historic wrong or desecrate a classic?

item.title: Inside Russia’s Secret Campaign of Sabotage in Europe
item.description: How Russian military intelligence is recruiting young people online to carry out espionage, arson, and other attacks across the Continent.

item.title: A Landscape Artist in Winter
item.description: In rural Scotland, Andy Goldsworthy, the sculptor famed for his use of natural materials, contemplates his own decay.

item.title: What Is Claude? Anthropic Doesn’t Know, Either
item.description: Researchers at the company are trying to understand their A.I. system’s mind—examining its neurons, running it through psychology experiments, and putting it on the therapy couch.

item.title: The Babies Kept in a Mysterious Los Angeles Mansion
item.description: A wealthy couple obtained dozens of children through surrogates. Did they want a family, or something else?

item.title: Can Ozempic Cure Addiction?
item.description: GLP-1 drugs, which have helped some people curb drug and alcohol use, may unlock a pathway to moderation.

item.title: The Trial of Gisèle Pelicot’s Rapists United France and Fractured Her Family
item.description: After fifty-one men were convicted, Pelicot became a feminist hero. But additional accusations left her children struggling to accept her new role.
